titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: James Bond (1900-1989) was a leading American ornithologist. Bond was born in Philadelphia and worked at the Academy of Natural Sciences, rising to become curator of birds. He was an expert in Caribbean birds and wrote the definitive book on the subject: Birds of the West Indies, first published in 1936. Bond won the Institute of Jamaica's Musgrave Medal in 1952; the Brewster Medal of the American Ornithologists Union in 1954; and the Leidy Medal of the Academy of Natural Sciences in 1975. Author Ian Fleming appropriated his name for his fictional spy.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of manuscripts, correspondence, and professional papers of James Bond and volumes of works by James and Mary Wickham Bond. Manuscripts in the collection include: autographed copies of chapters of Birds of the West Indies; typescript corrections for new editions of the book; a typescript draft of The World of James Bond, a biography by David R. Contosta; and a typescript for "A New Race of Chat Tanager from the Dominican Republic," by Bond and Annabelle Dod, with some related correspondence and notes. Other professional correspondence in the collection (incoming and outgoing), dating from 1939 to 1973, relates to the editing and publication of other books and articles, sightings of birds, identification of species, and requests for reprints. Correspondence dating from 1975 to 1979 is largely made up of letters between Bond and the secretary of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia. The collection includes copies of books by James and Mary Wickham Bond, reprints, and supplements to the Checklist of Birds of the West Indies. Other materials in the collection include photographic portraits of Bond; a set of printing plates for illustrations in Bond's book on Mt. Desert birds; medals awarded to Bond for his work; and a scrapbook of photographs and articles about Ian Fleming's use of James Bond's name.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: Free Library of Pennsylvania: James Bond collection.
